name: QuickLend Pro Annual IT Audit FY2025
scope_description: Comprehensive IT audit of the QuickLend Pro digital lending platform covering application infrastructure, data security controls, and regulatory compliance. The platform processes approximately 50,000 loan applications per month and handles sensitive financial data including SSNs, bank account numbers, and credit reports. Infrastructure includes hybrid cloud deployment with on-premises Oracle database servers and AWS-hosted application tier.
objectives: Evaluate the design and operating effectiveness of IT general controls across the lending platform
Assess compliance with PCI-DSS v4.0 requirements for cardholder data protection
Evaluate access control mechanisms protecting sensitive borrower data
Review change management processes for platform stability and integrity
Assess backup and disaster recovery readiness for business continuity
Identify control deficiencies and provide actionable remediation recommendations
methodology: Risk-based audit approach aligned with ISACA IT Audit Framework. Control testing included inquiry, observation, inspection of documentation, and re-performance of selected controls. Sampling methodology followed ISACA guidance with sample sizes based on population and control frequency.
executive_summary: The audit identified several significant control deficiencies requiring management attention. While the organization has established foundational IT controls, gaps exist in privileged access management, change management segregation, and disaster recovery testing. Seven findings were identified, including two rated as critical severity related to shared service account credentials and lack of multi-factor authentication on administrative accounts. Immediate remediation of critical findings is recommended.
notes: Client was cooperative throughout the audit. IT team provided requested evidence within agreed-upon timelines. Follow-up audit recommended for Q2 2026 to validate remediation.

audit_areas.name: Access Control
audit_areas.description: Controls for identity management, authentication, authorization, and access monitoring.
audit_areas.notes: Significant gaps identified in privileged access management and MFA enforcement.

controls.title: User Account Provisioning Process
controls.description: Verify that a formal, documented process exists for provisioning user accounts.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Obtain the user provisioning policy/procedure document. 2. Select a sample of 25 user accounts created in the past 6 months. 3. For each sampled account, verify that an approved access request exists.
controls.expected_evidence: User provisioning policy document, sample access request forms with approvals
controls.auditor_notes: Formal provisioning process in place using ServiceNow. All 25 sampled accounts had approved access requests. Process well-documented and followed consistently.

controls.title: User Account De-Provisioning (Termination)
controls.description: Verify that user accounts are disabled or removed promptly when an employee is terminated.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Obtain a list of employees terminated in the past 6 months from HR. 2. Cross-reference against active accounts.
controls.expected_evidence: HR termination list, Active Directory disable date reports
controls.auditor_notes: 3 of 25 sampled terminated users had accounts active for more than 5 business days post-termination. HR notification process has a manual step that occasionally delays IT notification. Average de-provisioning time was 2.8 days; however, outliers reached 8 days.

controls.title: Password Policy Enforcement
controls.description: Verify that password policies enforce minimum complexity, length, and rotation requirements.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Review the documented password policy. 2. Extract Active Directory password policy settings.
controls.expected_evidence: Password policy document, Active Directory Group Policy settings
controls.auditor_notes: Password policy requires minimum 14 characters, complexity enabled, 90-day rotation, 24 password history. Account lockout after 5 failed attempts with 30-minute lockout duration. Meets or exceeds all framework requirements.

controls.title: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
controls.description: Verify that multi-factor authentication is enforced for all remote access and privileged accounts.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Obtain MFA policy. 2. Test VPN login for MFA. 3. Test admin console login for MFA.
controls.expected_evidence: MFA policy, enrollment statistics, VPN configuration
controls.auditor_notes: MFA is enforced for VPN access and general user SSO. However, 12 domain administrator accounts and 8 database administrator accounts do not have MFA enabled. Legacy RADIUS authentication on the Oracle database management console allows password-only access. This represents a critical gap for privileged access.

controls.title: Privileged Access Management (PAM)
controls.description: Verify that privileged accounts are subject to enhanced controls.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Obtain a complete list of all privileged accounts. 2. Verify business justification and named owner.
controls.expected_evidence: Privileged account inventory, PAM tool reports
controls.auditor_notes: No dedicated PAM solution deployed. Privileged credentials are stored in a shared spreadsheet (encrypted but not access-controlled). Three production service accounts share the same password which has not been rotated in 14 months. No session recording for privileged access.

controls.title: Periodic Access Reviews
controls.description: Verify that user access rights are reviewed at least quarterly for privileged accounts.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Obtain the access review policy. 2. Request evidence of completed reviews.
controls.expected_evidence: Access review policy, completed review sign-offs
controls.auditor_notes: Semi-annual access reviews are conducted for standard accounts with 92% completion rate. However, privileged account reviews are not performed on a quarterly basis as required. Last privileged access review was 7 months ago.

controls.title: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
controls.description: Verify that access is granted through defined roles aligned to job functions.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Obtain role definition matrix. 2. Select 15 users and verify role assignments.
controls.expected_evidence: RBAC matrix, IAM system role configuration
controls.auditor_notes: Well-defined RBAC model implemented in Okta. 15 sampled users all had roles matching their job function. Role definitions documented and approved by business process owners. Minor finding: 2 users had roles from prior positions that were not removed during transfer.

controls.title: Segregation of Duties (SoD)
controls.description: Verify that access controls enforce segregation of incompatible duties.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Obtain SoD conflict matrix. 2. Run SoD conflict report.
controls.auditor_notes: SoD matrix defined and enforced in the ERP system. No critical SoD violations identified. Two low-risk conflicts documented with compensating controls approved by the CFO.

findings.title: Privileged Accounts Lack Multi-Factor Authentication
findings.description: Twelve domain administrator accounts and eight database administrator accounts do not enforce multi-factor authentication. The Oracle database management console uses legacy RADIUS authentication that supports password-only access, bypassing the organization's MFA controls. These accounts have direct access to production systems containing sensitive borrower data including SSNs and financial records.
findings.root_cause: Legacy authentication infrastructure for the Oracle database management console does not support modern MFA protocols. The migration to a compatible authentication method was deprioritized due to competing project demands.
findings.business_impact: Compromised privileged credentials could result in unauthorized access to all borrower records (approximately 2.3 million active records). Potential for regulatory sanctions under GLBA, state data breach notification requirements, and loss of customer trust. Estimated financial exposure: $5-15 million including breach notification costs, regulatory fines, and litigation.
findings.recommendation: 1. Implement MFA for all domain administrator accounts within 30 days using existing Okta integration. 2. Deploy a SAML-capable authentication proxy for the Oracle management console within 60 days. 3. Implement a PAM solution to enforce MFA checkout for all privileged sessions. 4. Disable legacy RADIUS authentication after migration.
findings.management_response: Accepted. IT has initiated an emergency project to enable MFA for all domain admin accounts by January 15, 2026. Oracle console migration to SAML is scheduled for Q1 2026. PAM solution RFP issued November 2025.

risk_rating.rationale: High likelihood due to credential reuse patterns observed in industry. Severe impact due to volume of PII accessible.

findings.title: Service Accounts Using Shared Credentials Without Rotation
findings.description: Three production service accounts (svc_lending_app, svc_credit_check, svc_payment_proc) share the same password which has not been rotated in 14 months. These accounts have direct database access to loan application records containing PII. Credentials are stored in an encrypted spreadsheet accessible to 15 IT staff members without audit trail of access.
findings.root_cause: No PAM solution in place. Service account password rotation was a manual process that was neglected after the responsible administrator departed. No automated monitoring for service account credential age.
findings.business_impact: Shared credentials across three critical service accounts create a single point of compromise. Any of the 15 staff with spreadsheet access could use these credentials without attribution. Stale passwords increase vulnerability to brute force and credential stuffing attacks.
findings.recommendation: 1. Immediately rotate all three service account passwords to unique, complex credentials. 2. Implement a PAM solution with automated credential rotation (90-day maximum). 3. Restrict service account credentials to need-to-know basis. 4. Implement monitoring for service account interactive logon attempts.
findings.management_response: Accepted. Service account passwords rotated on November 1, 2025. PAM solution implementation targeted for Q1 2026 as part of the broader privileged access project.

risk_rating.rationale: High likelihood due to shared credentials and wide access. Severe impact due to direct database access to PII.

findings.title: Delayed User De-Provisioning for Terminated Employees
findings.description: Testing of 25 terminated employee accounts revealed that 3 accounts (12%) remained active for more than 5 business days after the termination date. The maximum delay observed was 8 business days. The de-provisioning SLA requires same-day deactivation for involuntary terminations and 3 business days for voluntary terminations.
findings.root_cause: HR termination notification to IT relies on a manual email process. During peak periods, HR notification can be delayed by 2-3 business days. No automated integration between the HRIS and Active Directory for termination events.
findings.business_impact: Active accounts for terminated employees create a window of unauthorized access risk, particularly for involuntary terminations where the departing employee may have motivation for malicious activity.
findings.recommendation: 1. Implement automated HRIS-to-AD integration for termination events using the existing SCIM connector. 2. Establish a daily reconciliation report comparing HR active employee list against AD active accounts. 3. Implement compensating control of immediate VPN and email suspension upon HR notification, prior to full de-provisioning.
findings.management_response: Accepted. SCIM integration project approved and scheduled for Q1 2026. Daily reconciliation report implemented as interim control effective December 1, 2025.

risk_rating.rationale: Moderate likelihood as delays are intermittent. Moderate impact limited to individual account access scope.

audit_areas.name: Change Management
audit_areas.description: Controls for managing changes to IT systems, applications, and infrastructure.
audit_areas.notes: Change process exists but segregation between development and production needs strengthening.

controls.title: Change Management Policy and Process
controls.description: Verify that a formal change management policy exists.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Obtain the current change management policy.
controls.auditor_notes: Comprehensive change management policy in place, approved by CTO in March 2025. Defines standard, normal, and emergency change categories.

controls.title: Change Approval Authority
controls.description: Verify that changes are approved by authorized personnel prior to implementation.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Review the approval authority matrix. 2. For sampled changes, verify approvals.
controls.expected_evidence: Approval authority matrix, change tickets with approvals
controls.auditor_notes: Approval authority matrix exists. 22 of 25 sampled changes had proper approval. 3 changes were deployed before formal approval was recorded in the ITSM tool. No formal CAB exists; approvals are handled by individual team leads.

controls.title: Segregation of Development and Production Environments
controls.description: Verify that development, testing, and production environments are separated.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Review environment architecture. 2. Verify developer access to production.
controls.expected_evidence: Environment architecture diagram, access control lists
controls.auditor_notes: Separate AWS accounts for dev, staging, and production. However, 4 senior developers have IAM roles granting them direct write access to production S3 buckets and Lambda functions for 'emergency fixes.' These emergency accesses are not logged or reviewed.

controls.title: Emergency Change Procedures
controls.description: Verify that a defined emergency change process exists.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Review the emergency change procedure. 2. Identify emergency changes in past 6 months.
controls.expected_evidence: Emergency change procedure, emergency change tickets
controls.auditor_notes: Emergency change procedure documented and followed. 8 emergency changes in the past 6 months (6.5% of total changes), all with documented post-implementation reviews. Acceptable ratio.

findings.title: No Formal Change Advisory Board (CAB)
findings.description: Changes to production systems are approved by individual team leads without a formal Change Advisory Board review process. High-risk and major changes do not receive multi-stakeholder review before implementation. Emergency changes bypass all approval workflows with only verbal authorization.
findings.root_cause: The organization has grown rapidly from 50 to 200 IT staff in 18 months. The change management process has not scaled to match, retaining the informal approval structure suited to a smaller team.
findings.business_impact: Without CAB review, high-risk changes may not receive adequate risk assessment from all affected stakeholders. This increases the probability of failed changes and unplanned downtime for the lending platform.
findings.recommendation: 1. Establish a formal CAB with representation from IT operations, security, application development, and business stakeholders. 2. Define CAB meeting cadence (weekly recommended). 3. Require CAB approval for all high-risk and major changes. 4. Implement a formal emergency change approval process with documented authorization.
findings.management_response: Accepted. CAB charter drafted and scheduled for CTO approval by January 2026. Weekly CAB meetings to commence February 2026.

findings.title: Developers Retain Production Write Access
findings.description: Four senior developers have AWS IAM roles granting direct write access to production S3 buckets and Lambda functions. This access was provisioned for emergency fix capabilities but is not time-limited, monitored, or subject to regular review. Developers can modify production code without going through the CI/CD pipeline or change management process.
findings.root_cause: IAM roles were created during a production incident 9 months ago and were not revoked after the incident was resolved. No process exists to review and revoke temporary elevated access.
findings.business_impact: Developers with production write access can introduce unauthorized changes, potentially affecting the integrity of loan processing calculations and financial transactions. This also violates SOX segregation of duties requirements.
findings.recommendation: 1. Immediately revoke standing production write access from developer IAM roles. 2. Implement a just-in-time (JIT) access mechanism requiring approval and time limitation for emergency production access. 3. Enable CloudTrail logging and alerting for any direct production modifications. 4. Conduct a review of all changes made via these IAM roles in the past 9 months.
findings.management_response: Accepted. Developer production access revoked on November 15, 2025. JIT access mechanism under evaluation.

audit_areas.name: Data Backup and Recovery
audit_areas.description: Controls for data backup operations, integrity verification, and disaster recovery.
audit_areas.notes: Backup execution is reliable but DR testing has not been conducted in the current fiscal year.

controls.title: Backup Policy and Strategy
controls.description: Verify that a formal data backup policy exists.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Obtain the data backup policy. 2. Verify RPO/RTO alignment.
controls.auditor_notes: Comprehensive backup policy in place. RPO of 1 hour for production databases, RTO of 4 hours for critical systems. Policy reviewed and approved in June 2025.

controls.title: Backup Execution and Scheduling
controls.description: Verify that backups are executed per defined schedule.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Obtain backup job schedules. 2. Review success/failure rates.
controls.auditor_notes: Automated backup schedule in place. 30-day review shows 99.2% success rate (3 failures out of 378 jobs, all resolved within 4 hours). AWS Backup for cloud resources, Veeam for on-premises Oracle databases.

controls.title: Disaster Recovery Testing
controls.description: Verify that the DRP is tested at least annually.
controls.test_procedure: 1. Obtain DR test results. 2. Verify RTO/RPO achievement.
controls.auditor_notes: Last full DR test was conducted in March 2024 (20 months ago). A tabletop exercise was conducted in September 2025 but no functional recovery test was performed. The March 2024 test revealed RTO of 6.5 hours against a 4-hour target, and remediation actions from that test are still partially outstanding.

findings.title: Disaster Recovery Plan Not Tested Within 12 Months
findings.description: The last full disaster recovery test was conducted in March 2024, exceeding the 12-month testing requirement by 8 months. The March 2024 test revealed that actual RTO was 6.5 hours against the 4-hour target, and several remediation items from that test remain outstanding. A tabletop exercise was conducted in September 2025 but does not constitute a functional recovery test.
findings.root_cause: DR testing was postponed twice due to competing priorities (platform migration and a production incident). No mechanism exists to enforce DR testing deadlines, and DR testing is not tied to management KPIs.
findings.business_impact: Without validated DR capability, the organization cannot confirm it can recover the lending platform within the defined RTO/RPO targets. In a disaster scenario, actual recovery time could significantly exceed targets, resulting in extended platform downtime and potential loss of in-flight loan applications.
findings.recommendation: 1. Schedule and execute a full DR recovery test within 60 days. 2. Address all outstanding remediation items from the March 2024 test before the next test. 3. Add DR testing completion as a management KPI. 4. Implement a compliance calendar with automated reminders for recurring obligations.
findings.management_response: Accepted. Full DR test scheduled for February 2026. Outstanding remediation items assigned to infrastructure team lead with January 2026 deadline.

findings.title: Recovery Time Objective Not Achievable Based on Last Test
findings.description: The March 2024 DR test demonstrated an actual recovery time of 6.5 hours for the lending platform, which exceeds the defined 4-hour RTO by 62.5%. The primary bottleneck was Oracle database restoration, which took 4 hours alone due to the database size (2.8 TB) and the restore process requiring manual intervention for tablespace recovery.
findings.root_cause: Database has grown significantly since RTO targets were set. Restore procedures have not been optimized for the current database size. No incremental restore capability is in place.
findings.business_impact: If a disaster occurs, the lending platform will be unavailable for at least 6.5 hours (and potentially longer given further database growth), exceeding the business commitment of 4-hour RTO.
findings.recommendation: 1. Re-evaluate RTO targets based on current infrastructure capabilities and business requirements. 2. Implement Oracle Data Guard for near-real-time database replication to reduce failover time. 3. Optimize restore procedures and consider incremental restore capabilities. 4. Validate revised RTO through testing.
findings.management_response: Accepted. Oracle Data Guard implementation approved in the FY2026 infrastructure budget. RTO review meeting scheduled with business stakeholders for January 2026.
